comments.text: First sentence is clever but vague. What does 'doesn't want to stay basketball' actually mean? Second version frontloads the value proposition: this is about governance and power. 'Disguised as' is more precise than 'doesn't want to stay.' Readers need to know what they're signing up for in the first 10 seconds.
comments.original_text:
## What Is This Game?

Pinwheel Fates is a basketball league that doesn't want to stay basketball. AI hoopers play 3v3 games automatically. You never touch the ball. What you touch are **the rules** — and through the rules, *everything*.
comments.suggestion:
## What Is This Game?

Pinwheel Fates is a governance game disguised as a basketball league. AI hoopers play 3v3 games automatically while you—the governor—rewrite the rules of reality. You never touch the ball. You control **the rules**, and through the rules, *everything*.

anchor.text:
## What Is This Game?

Pinwheel Fates is a basketball league that doesn't want to stay basketball. AI hoopers play 3v3 games automatically. You never touch the ball. What you touch are **the rules** — and through the rules, *everything*.

comments.text: The rhythm breaks at 'What you touch are.' Restructuring with a dash and 'something more powerful' creates anticipation before the reveal. It makes the reader lean forward instead of just receiving information.
comments.original_text: AI hoopers play 3v3 games automatically. You never touch the ball. What you touch are **the rules** — and through the rules, *everything*.
comments.suggestion: AI hoopers play 3v3 games automatically. You never touch the ball—you touch something more powerful: **the rules**. And through the rules, *everything*.

anchor.text: AI hoopers play 3v3 games automatically. You never touch the ball. What you touch are **the rules** — and through the rules, *everything*.

comments.text: Period after 'plain English' creates a full stop before examples—should be a colon to introduce them. 'Reads what you wrote, figures out what it means' is redundant with 'interprets your intent' used later. Streamlined version is tighter.
comments.original_text: You propose changes in plain English. "Make three-pointers worth 10 points." "The floor is lava." "Nobody can shoot until they've passed three times." The game reads what you wrote, figures out what it means for the simulation, and shows you what it thinks you're asking for.
comments.suggestion: You propose changes in plain English: "Make three-pointers worth 10 points." "The floor is lava." "Nobody can shoot until they've passed three times." The game interprets your intent, maps it to the simulation, and shows you what it understood.

anchor.text: You propose changes in plain English. "Make three-pointers worth 10 points." "The floor is lava." "Nobody can shoot until they've passed three times." The game reads what you wrote, figures out what it means for the simulation, and shows you what it thinks you're asking for.

comments.text: The mechanism here is the core innovation but it's buried in soft language. 'The game reads what you wrote, figures out' sounds magical rather than systematic. Readers need to trust this works. 'AI interpreter translates...into simulation parameters' is concrete. Also: 'shows you what it thinks you're asking for' undersells the precision—it should be 'exactly what will change.'
comments.original_text: You propose changes in plain English. "Make three-pointers worth 10 points." "The floor is lava." "Nobody can shoot until they've passed three times." The game reads what you wrote, figures out what it means for the simulation, and shows you what it thinks you're asking for. You confirm, the league votes, and if it passes — the next game runs in a different world.
comments.suggestion: You propose changes in plain English: "Make three-pointers worth 10 points." "The floor is lava." "Nobody can shoot until they've passed three times." An AI interpreter translates your proposal into simulation parameters and shows you exactly what will change. You confirm or revise. The league votes. If it passes, the next game runs under your new rules.

anchor.text: You propose changes in plain English. "Make three-pointers worth 10 points." "The floor is lava." "Nobody can shoot until they've passed three times." The game reads what you wrote, figures out what it means for the simulation, and shows you what it thinks you're asking for. You confirm, the league votes, and if it passes — the next game runs in a different world.

comments.text: Three short declarative sentences in a row create a plodding rhythm. Combining the first two with a dash and adding 'consequences cascading' gives motion. 'Rewrites reality' is more visceral than 'rewrites the rules' (which we just said).
comments.original_text: The game simulates itself. Games run every few minutes. Every few rounds, the Floor tallies all the votes, rewrites the rules, and the next batch of games runs under whatever reality you've collectively authored.
comments.suggestion: The game simulates itself—games run every few minutes, consequences cascading in real time. Every few rounds, the Floor tallies votes and rewrites reality. The next batch of games plays out in whatever world you've collectively authored.

anchor.text: The game simulates itself. Games run every few minutes. Every few rounds, the Floor tallies all the votes, rewrites the rules, and the next batch of games runs under whatever reality you've collectively authored.
anchor.context_before: e runs in a different world.

comments.text: 'Pick one' then 'choose' is repetitive. 'Locked in for the season' sounds restrictive without explaining why that matters. New version explains the commitment clearly and gives three concrete decision criteria. 'Conspire with' is flavorful but might confuse new users about whether collaboration is allowed.
comments.original_text:
```
/join
```

The bot shows you the teams. Pick one. You're locked in for the season — choose the hoopers you believe in, or the governors you want to conspire with.
comments.suggestion:
```
/join
```

The bot shows you available teams. Pick one—you'll stay with them for the entire season. Choose based on the hoopers' stats, the team's strategy, or the governors you want to work with.

anchor.text:
```
/join
```

The bot shows you the teams. Pick one. You're locked in for the season — choose the hoopers you believe in, or the governors you want to conspire with.

comments.text: The command appears before the user knows why they'd use it. Adding context ('Check your token balance anytime') tells them what the command does. 'Political currency' requires them to map metaphor to mechanics—'three types of tokens' is clearer for first read.

comments.text: 'Put something on the Floor' uses game jargon before it's established. 'Submit a rule change for the league to vote on' is concrete. Each token description now explains the mechanic first, then the strategic value. 'Save it for the vote that matters most' is vague—'when the outcome really matters' is clearer guidance.
comments.original_text:
-   **PROPOSE** (2) — Put something on the Floor. This is agenda-setting power. The most valuable token in the game.
    
-   **AMEND** (2) — Rewrite someone else's proposal before it goes to vote. You can't stop them from proposing, but you can change what they proposed.
    
-   **BOOST** (2) — Double your voting weight on a single vote. Save it for the vote that matters most.
comments.suggestion:
-   **PROPOSE** (2) — Submit a rule change for the league to vote on. This lets you set the agenda.
    
-   **AMEND** (2) — Rewrite someone else's proposal before the vote. You can't block their proposal, but you can change what gets voted on.
    
-   **BOOST** (2) — Double your voting power on one proposal. Use it when the outcome really matters.

anchor.text:
-   **PROPOSE** (2) — Put something on the Floor. This is agenda-setting power. The most valuable token in the game.
    
-   **AMEND** (2) — Rewrite someone else's proposal before it goes to vote. You can't stop them from proposing, but you can change what they proposed.
    
-   **BOOST** (2) — Double your voting weight on a single vote. Save it for the vote that matters most.

comments.text: 'Three buttons' assumes a UI that might not exist (could be Discord reactions, slash command options, etc.). 'Three options' is interface-agnostic. Each option now explicitly states the cost/no cost upfront—users shouldn't have to read to the end to know if they're spending resources. Parenthetical costs are scannable.
comments.original_text:
Three buttons:

-   **Confirm** — Spend the token. Post it to the Floor. Let the league decide.
    
-   **Revise** — Rewrite it. The game re-interprets. No tokens spent until you confirm.
    
-   **Cancel** — Walk away. No cost.
comments.suggestion:
You'll see three options:

-   **Confirm** — Spend your PROPOSE token and post this to the Floor for voting
    
-   **Revise** — Edit your proposal and see a new interpretation (no cost)
    
-   **Cancel** — Discard this proposal (no cost)

anchor.text:
Three buttons:

-   **Confirm** — Spend the token. Post it to the Floor. Let the league decide.
    
-   **Revise** — Rewrite it. The game re-interprets. No tokens spent until you confirm.
    
-   **Cancel** — Walk away. No cost.

comments.text: 'Proposes three-pointers worth 10' is grammatically incomplete—missing the verb. Should be 'proposes making' or 'proposes that three-pointers be worth 10.' The former is cleaner.
comments.original_text: Someone proposes three-pointers worth 10. It passes. Then someone moves the Elam Ending to start after the 1st quarter with a tiny margin.
comments.suggestion: Someone proposes making three-pointers worth 10. It passes. Then someone moves the Elam Ending to start after the 1st quarter with a tiny margin.

anchor.text: Someone proposes three-pointers worth 10. It passes. Then someone moves the Elam Ending to start after the 1st quarter with a tiny margin.

comments.text: 'What you can't see from inside the system' is philosophical. What specifically can't you see? 'Information asymmetries' is precise and immediately valuable. The second sentence gives concrete examples. This feature is a competitive advantage in understanding the meta-game—make that clear.
comments.original_text: The reports never tell you what to do. They show you what you can't see from inside the system. What you do with that information is governance.
comments.suggestion: The reports never tell you what to do—they surface information asymmetries. You see voting blocs forming, power concentrating, and consequences you didn't anticipate. What you do with that information is governance.

anchor.text: The reports never tell you what to do. They show you what you can't see from inside the system. What you do with that information is governance.

comments.text: The word 'destroy' lands with punch but then stops. 'Tear apart and rebuild' gives the reader the complete arc—destruction AND creation—which is what the game actually is. It's the promise of transformation, not just demolition.
comments.original_text: Welcome to Pinwheel Fates. You are about to help destroy basketball.
comments.suggestion: Welcome to Pinwheel Fates. You're about to tear basketball apart and rebuild it into something unrecognizable.

anchor.text: Welcome to Pinwheel Fates. You are about to help destroy basketball.

comments.text: 'Whatever you make it' is vague inspiration. This document needs to convince people the system is robust enough to actually deliver on that promise. 'Depends entirely on your governance' ties back to the core mechanic and makes the player agency concrete.
comments.original_text: **It starts as basketball. It becomes whatever you make it.**
comments.suggestion: **It starts as basketball. Where it ends depends entirely on your governance.**

anchor.text: **It starts as basketball. It becomes whatever you make it.**
anchor.context_before: ugh real games in real time.

comments.text: The colon promises a list, but 'political currency' is abstract. Adding 'three types' and 'each precious' frames what's coming as valuable and limited before the reader even sees the tokens. It creates desire.
comments.original_text: You start with political currency:
comments.suggestion: You start with three types of political currency, each precious:

anchor.text: You start with political currency:

comments.text: 'Someone else's leverage' is abstract. What does that actually mean for gameplay? 'Secondary market for political influence' and 'agenda-setting power' are concrete mechanisms. If this token economy is a differentiator, say what it enables, not just that it exists.
comments.original_text: Tokens regenerate every tally round (every 3 rounds of games). They accumulate if unspent. They're tradeable — your PROPOSE tokens are someone else's leverage.
comments.suggestion: Tokens regenerate every tally round (every 3 rounds of games) and accumulate if unspent. They're tradeable, creating a secondary market for political influence—your unused PROPOSE token is someone else's agenda-setting power.

anchor.text: Tokens regenerate every tally round (every 3 rounds of games). They accumulate if unspent. They're tradeable — your PROPOSE tokens are someone else's leverage.

comments.text: 'A few seconds' is technical timing. 'A moment' maintains the magic. The addition explains what's actually happening in this exchange: imagination becoming code. That's the core miracle of the game.
comments.original_text: The game thinks for a few seconds, then sends you a private interpretation:
comments.suggestion: The game thinks for a moment, then sends you a private interpretation—a translation of your imagination into simulation mechanics:

anchor.text: The game thinks for a few seconds, then sends you a private interpretation:

comments.text: Two short sentences describing the same action. An em dash connects them more fluidly since the second elaborates on the first. This is a rhythm issue, not a meaning issue.
comments.original_text: The game did the technical work. It figured out which simulation lever to pull and told you what it thinks will happen.
comments.suggestion: The game did the technical work—it figured out which simulation lever to pull and told you what it thinks will happen.

anchor.text: The game did the technical work. It figured out which simulation lever to pull and told you what it thinks will happen.

comments.text: 'Commit' is terse and could read as dismissive or unclear. 'Votes are final once submitted' is a clear, neutral statement of the rule. Users asking this question are probably anxious about making a mistake—reassure them with clarity, not attitude.
comments.original_text:
**Can I change my vote?**  
No. Commit.
comments.suggestion:
**Can I change my vote?**  
No. Votes are final once submitted.

anchor.text:
**Can I change my vote?**  
No. Commit.

comments.text: First bullet uses three sentence fragments where commas would be more natural. The other bullets work as fragments. Parallel structure would mean all three get the same treatment, but the first one reads choppy as-is.

-   **Revise** — Rewrite it. The game re-interprets. No tokens spent until you confirm.
    
-   **Cancel** — Walk away. No cost.

comments.text: Colon suggests what follows is an explanation or list. This is a restatement/clarification, which calls for an em dash. Minor punctuation precision.
